awd_titl_txt: Dissertation Grant: Antibiotic Resistance, Planetary Crisis, and Bacteriophage Futures in the 21st Century
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports doctoral dissertation research that focuses on critical socio-technical facets of antibiotic resistant pathogens (also known as "superbugs"). It will examine the scientific, economic, technological, and ecological impacts of antibiotic-resistant infectious entities on human society in the 21st century. In doing so, it will uncover the cultural values, political experiences, and historical contingencies that lead to the dominance of antibiotics for infection-control in 20th century. It will then focus on an alternative approach that uses bacteriophage technologies as a promising frontier in a post-antibiotic world. The results of this research will serve to create civic awareness and to promote informed public participation in research, design, and agendas of emerging life-sciences. It will also be useful to policymakers, regulators and scientists in developing of socially-grounded strategies for confronting antibiotic resistance at local, national, and global scales.

This research project examines historical and socio-technical dimensions of the diminishing efficacy of antibiotics. It will outline the crisis, the causes, and the catastrophic potentials of antibiotic failure; that will in turn serve as a locus of an examination of the political and ethical stakes in the production of scientific knowledge, and of the ongoing challenges in deployments of resurgent technologies like bacteriophages to secure human wellbeing. The results of this project will further our understanding of the nexus of extant industrial practices, toxic ecologies, and recalcitrant organisms implicated in the development of planetary antibiotic resistance, conceptualized as the contemporary legacy of the 20th century mass-deployment of synthetic antimicrobial agents; bacteriophages provide a promising frontier in a post-antibiotic, having the potential to unbind that nexus. This project will also reveal reticulated relationships between scientific epistemologies, technological materials, political histories, cultural practices, and planetary futures; it will generate wider conceptions of the ecology of human-bacterial-animal-viral entanglements and their complexity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Antibiotic-resistant pathogens travel across environments and borders, threatening the reversal of the once-widespread twentieth century successes of antibiotics across the planet. Whether in healthcare or food production, bioremediation or biotechnology, antibiotic resistance promises an end to a century of public confidence in treating bacterial infections. This doctoral dissertation research explores four interconnected historical sites in India, Georgia, and the United States. Located at a crossroads of biomedical research, plural health care systems, and cosmologies comprising secular-scientific and mythic-religious reason, these sites offer historical grounds for reckoning with a post-antibiotic era through the deployment of bacteriophage (literally, bacteria-eating) viruses. This alternative Soviet scientific strategy of infection control was rendered moribund against dominant antibiotics in the twentieth century, but is increasingly returning as a revenant scientific strategy. Through the Cold War history of the bacteriophage, and its secular and religious genealogies, this research explores the reconfiguration of contagion and bio(in)security in the twnety first century.

Pursuing former Cold War geographies, this project examines the historical relationship between science and epistemology: (1) Microbiologists increasingly confront deskilling and scientific failure against antibiotic resistant pathogens, leading them to devise alternative strategies of infection control with bacteriophages, which are reconfiguring historically dominant paradigms of enmity central to modern germ-theory. (2) Bacteriophage scientists at a Soviet-era facility in Tbilisi, Georgia navigate possibilities and perils in their efforts at resurrecting an alternative science featuring bacteriophage viruses once rendered moribund against Western antibiotics, which are increasingly being regarded by them as a mode of technoscientific salvation for twenty-first century infection-control. (3) Bacteriophage viruses were first described in 1896 near Allahabad, India, at the confluence (sangam) of the rivers Ganga and Yamuna. Beside these riverwaters, considered healing and purifying in local religious and therapeutic traditions, priests and Ayurvedic doctors jostle with biomedical specialists and local phage biologists, charting therapeutic futures for confronting antibiotic failure in a place genealogically marked by the pre-discovery of bacteriophages. Considered together, they offer a historical epistemology of time--a cosmotechnics--at the intersection of faith, science, ecology, and cure. (4) Researchers and regulators in American bioscientific bastions like Boston scramble to confront a world without antibiotics, pursuing reconfigurations of biologies, biotechnologies, and biocapital with bacteriophages--a Soviet tool of promissory biosecurity, offering new modes of thinking about human-bacterial-viral symbiosis, that carries the Cold War-era trace of allied scientific histories such as molecular biology and genetics within it. 

Long divided by geopolitics and quality of life, these allegedly-Third, Second and First worlds no longer adhere to those political hierarchies. Instead, they are interconnected by forms of scientific life and undoing featuring bacteriophages as a promising frontier in post-antibiotic worlds. Antibiotic-resistant pathogens are human-bred organisms: world-altering bio-environmental ramifications of the mass-deployment of antibiotics in twentieth century culture. With them, this dissertation contributes to three sets of historical literatures. First, it pursues the cumulative effects of the industrial age--its toxics and exposures--on ecosystems. Through the concept of the antibioticene, it adds heft to theorizations in environmental studies of the Anthropocene, the naming of a planetary geological epoch altered by human signatures. Second, through historical accounts of modernity and rationality, this project enquires how the deployment of antibiotics since the twentieth century has linked aspirations across scales, enabling a series of vital systems infrastructures securing the body of modern life: healthcare, livestock farming, biotechnologies, remediation. What happens to these vital, yet fragile, infrastructures that have made human life possible at vast scales when the sociotechnical object engineering them-the antibiotic-encounters its own ruination through a negative biological dialectic? Finally, this project tracks the unfolding of antibiotic-failure within connected geographic realms, contributing to historical and scientific accounts of the Cold War. Planetary flows of mutant microorganisms, and the decay of infrastructures historically constituted by antibiotics, evoke multiple experimental responses within these bioscientific realms, forging transnational movements of scientific equipment, experiences of endangerment, and epistemologies, which upend neat Global North/South divides. Through the analytic of waiting, this project unearths how provincialized forms of knowledge that have long been marginalized in scientific discourse, are emerging as frontline responses, linking geographies once carved by history yet, increasingly, conjoined by crisis.
